explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: The macro/inline used to obtain 'impl' — its expansion determines whether the assignment has side effects (calls, checks, traps) and whether removal of the lookup would change behavior.
OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Shown in the static call graph as the actual callee behind the table-get; its semantics (validation, possible side effects, return on error) affect whether the lookup and subsequent operations are meaningful.
OS_impl_condvar_table: The underlying table/object referenced by the macro — needed to know lifetime and visibility of the condition-variable objects and whether entries can be NULL/invalid (affects whether the code is ever effective).
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t: The struct type of 'impl' — required to know what members (notably the cv field) exist and whether accessing impl->cv is a no-op or has side effects.
pthread_cond_broadcast: The POSIX call invoked — required to know its observable effects (wakes waiting threads) so we can determine if calling it is behaviorally relevant or could be removed without effect.
pthread_cond_t: The type of impl->cv — knowing its semantics is needed to understand what broadcasting does and whether it has any interaction with other code.
OS_object_token_t: The token type used as input — needed to know whether dereferencing/using *token can be optimized away or has validation side effects.
OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR: The return-code constants the function uses — required to know whether the return value encodes meaningful observable behavior and how callers respond to these codes.
OS_CondVarWait_Impl, OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl, OS_CondVarSignal_Impl: Other operations that use the same condition variable — needed to see whether pthread_cond_broadcast influences other threads (e.g., waiting or signaling), so removing the broadcast would change program behavior.
OS_CondVarCreate_Impl, OS_CondVarDelete_Impl: Creation/destruction semantics for the condvar objects — required to determine object lifetime and whether broadcasts could be no-ops (e.g., on destroyed or uninitialized objects).
OS_CondVarLock_Impl, OS_CondVarUnlock_Impl: Lock/unlock operations that coordinate with wait/broadcast — required to understand synchronization protocol and whether a broadcast without matching locks/conditions is relevant.
These symbols collectively allow analysis of (1) whether the lookup and broadcast have any externally observable effects (wake threads, change synchronization), (2) whether the lookup or broadcast ever execute or are redundant given object lifecycle, and thus whether removing the code would not affect program behaviour (i.e., whether it is dead code).
